questions.text: Identify the tendon marked in the image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Flexor carpi radialis

Explanation:

  • The tendon marked in the image is the tendon of the flexor carpi radialis muscle.
  • Flexor carpi radialis muscle is a long flexor muscle lying in the anterior compartment of the forearm.
  • It arises in the humeral epicondyle, close to the wrist area.
  • It is a superficial muscle that becomes visible as the wrist flexes.

Muscles of Forearm:

  • Superficial flexor muscles: Origin, insertion, nerve supply and action:

(Options B, C)

  • Deep flexor muscles–origin, insertion, nerve supply and action:

Median nerve (Option D): Lies deep and does not appear as a tendon

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with multiple fractures of the humerus secondary to a fall from height. On examination, there is difficulty in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm and associated loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm. Which is the nerve most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Answer C - Musculocutaneous nerve:

  • The musculocutaneous nerve (C5–C7) arises from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus and primarily supplies the flexor muscles of the arm.

Key functions affected in this injury:

  • Elbow flexion → Impaired due to paralysis of biceps brachii, brachialis, and coracobrachialis.
  • Forearm supination → Weakened because biceps brachii is affected (but supination is not completely lost as the supinator muscle is intact).
  • Sensory loss → Over the lateral aspect of the forearm due to involvement of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, which is a branch of the musculocutaneous nerve.

Coracobrachialis:

  • Origin: Medial coracoid process ; Insertion: Medial aspect of middle humerus
  • Nerve supply: Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7)
  • Action: Flexion (+adduction) of arm at shoulder joint
  • May not be paralyzed in Erb’s palsy, as in case of Erb’s palsy: C5,C6 are compromised but C7 remains unaffected and hence Coracobrachialis is not paralyzed.

Muscles of arm:

Muscle

Attachments

Nerve supply

Action

Biceps brachii
  • Origin: Short head- Coracoid process ; Long head- Supragelnoid tubercle
  • Insertion: Radial tuberosity
  • Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C6)
  • Flexion and supination of forearm

Brachialis
  • Origin: anterior humerus
  • Insertion: coronoid process & ulnar tuberosity
  • Motor: Musculocutaneous nerve
  • Proprioceptive: Radial nerve
  • Flexion of forearm

Coraco- brachialis
  • Origin: medial coracoid process
  • Insertion: medial aspect of middle humerus
  • Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7)
  • Flexion of arm

Median nerve (option A): Motor: Controls most forearm flexors and thenar muscles, but does not significantly affect elbow flexion or supination. Sensory: Supplies the lateral palm and first three fingers, not the lateral forearm.

Radial nerve (option B): Motor: Affects wrist extension (wrist drop) and elbow extension, but not elbow flexion. Sensory: Supplies the posterior arm, forearm, and dorsum of the hand, not the lateral forearm.

Ulnar nerve (option D): Motor: Controls intrinsic hand muscles and some forearm flexors, but does not significantly affect elbow flexion or supination. Sensory: Involves the medial hand and little finger, not the lateral forearm.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is attached to the area marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Opponens pollicis

Explanation:

  • The opponens pollicis muscle is indeed attached to the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal. This muscle originates from the flexor retinaculum and the tubercles of the trapezium and scaphoid bones in the wrist. Its tendon inserts onto the palmar surface of the first metacarpal bone. The opponens pollicis muscle functions to oppose the thumb, allowing for its opposition to the other fingers, a key movement for precision grip.

Muscles of thenar eminence:

Muscle

Attachments

Nerve supply

Action

Abductor pollicis brevis

  • Origin: Scaphoid tubercle, crest of Trapezium and flexor retinaculum

  • Insertion: Base of proximal phalanx of thumb

  • Median nerve

  • Abduction of thumb

Flexor pollicis brevis

  • Origin: Capitate, crest of Trapezium and flexor retinaculum

  • Insertion: Base of proximal phalanx of thumb

  • Median nerve

  • Flexion of metacarpo-phalangeal joint of thumb

Opponens pollicis

  • Origin: crest of Trapezium and flexor retinaculum

  • Insertion: Lateral half of palmar surface of the shaft of thumb metacarpal

  • Median nerve

  • Opposition of thumb towards fingers

Adductor pollicis

  • Origin: Oblique head- base of 2nd-3rd metacarpal ; transverse head- shaft of 3rd metacarpal

  • Insertion: Base of proximal phalanx of thumb (medial aspect)

  • Ulnar nerve

  • Adduction of thumb

Abductor Pollicis Longus (Option A): The abductor pollicis longus muscle abducts the thumb but doesn't directly attach to the palm side of the first metacarpal.

Palmar Interossei (Option B): While palmar interossei muscles are in the vicinity of the first metacarpal bone, they are not specifically attached to the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal.

Flexor Pollicis Brevis (Option D): The flexor pollicis brevis muscle helps with thumb flexion and opposition but doesn't directly attach to the palm side of the first metacarpal.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient is presenting with wrist pain on the lateral side. On examination the following test was positive. Tendon sheaths of which two muscles have been involved?

choices.text: Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis longus
Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis longus

questions.solution:
Correct Option A) Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with lateral wrist pain and a positive Finkelstein test (most commonly performed for diagnosing De Quervain’s tenosynovitis).

 

De Quervain’s tenosynovitis involves the inflammation of the tendon sheaths of:

  • Abductor pollicis longus (APL)
  • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)

These tendons pass through the first dorsal compartment of the wrist.

 

Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis longus (option B): Extensor pollicis longus (EPL) is located in the third dorsal compartment and is not involved in De Quervain’s tenosynovitis.

Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis brevis (option C): Abductor pollicis brevis (APB) is part of the thenar muscles and does not pass through the first dorsal compartment.

Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis longus (option D): Extensor pollicis longus (EPL) is not affected, and abductor pollicis brevis (APB) is a thenar muscle.

questions.text: A patient presented with the extension of MCP joint and flexion of IP joints. Which muscle is affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Interossei and lumbricals

Explanation:

  • The interossei and lumbricals are responsible for flexion at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) and distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints, as well as extension at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint.
  • Dysfunction of these muscles, such as in ulnar nerve damage, leads to the characteristic posture of MCP extension and IP flexion, known as "claw hand."

Extensor digitorum (option A): This is incorrect because the extensor digitorum is primarily responsible for extending the MCP, PIP, and DIP joints. It does not cause the flexion of the IP joints with extension at the MCP joint.

Abductor pollicis longus (option C): This is incorrect because the abductor pollicis longus is involved in the abduction and extension of the thumb, not the flexion or extension of the fingers.

Abductor pollicis brevis (option D): This is incorrect because the abductor pollicis brevis is responsible for the abduction of the thumb and does not influence the MCP or IP joints of the fingers.

questions.text: Identify the sign in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Popeye sign

Explanation:

  • Popeye sign refers to a characteristic bulging of the biceps muscle belly in the upper arm due to a rupture of the long head of the biceps tendon. The proximal portion of the tendon retracts, causing the muscle to bunch up in the mid-upper arm, resembling Popeye’s biceps from the cartoon character.
  • It is often seen in older adults, particularly in those with a history of repetitive overhead activity or degenerative tendon changes.

Patients typically present with:

  • Sudden pain in the shoulder
  • Audible "pop"
  • Bruising
  • Weakness in elbow flexion and supination

 

Incorrect Options:

Hill-Sachs sign (option B): A cortical depression (compression fracture) in the posterolateral humeral head, caused by anterior shoulder dislocation. Best seen on X-ray or MRI, not a visible sign like Popeye sign.

Griesinger sign (option C): Seen in lateral sinus thrombophlebitis (complication of otitis media or mastoiditis). Characterized by tenderness and swelling over the mastoid process due to venous congestion.

Rising sun sign (option D): Seen in orbital floor fractures, indicating prolapse of orbital contents into the maxillary sinus, resembling a "rising sun" on imaging.

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box?

choices.text: Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis

questions.solution:
Answer: A) Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

Explanation:

The anatomical snuff box is a triangular depression on the lateral aspect of the wrist, best seen when the thumb is extended. It is bounded laterally by the tendons of:

  • Abductor pollicis longus (APL)
  • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)

Boundaries of the Anatomical Snuff Box:

  1. Lateral (Radial) Boundary:
    • Abductor pollicis longus (APL)
    • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)
  2. Medial (Ulnar) Boundary:
    • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL)
  3. Floor:
    • Scaphoid & Trapezium bones
    • Radial artery passes through
  4. Roof:
    • Skin & Superficial branch of the radial nerve

Contents

  • Radial Artery: Crosses the floor of the anatomical snuff box.

Tenderness in the anatomical snuff box following a fall on an outstretched hand strongly suggests a scaphoid fracture, as the scaphoid bone lies in the floor of the anatomical snuff box. This type of fracture is common and can have complications due to poor blood supply.

Incorrect Options:

Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis (option B): EPL forms the medial boundary, not lateral. Abductor pollicis brevis (APB) is not involved in the snuff box boundaries.

Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis (option C): EPL is the medial boundary, while EPB is lateral. The second lateral tendon (APL) is missing.

Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis (option D): Abductor pollicis brevis (APB) is not part of the snuff box.

questions.text: The image showed a normal elbow. What is the structure marked in the image called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Capitulum

Explanation:

The capitulum is a rounded knob-like structure located on the distal end of the humerus bone. It articulates with the radius bone to form the radiocapitular joint, which allows for flexion and extension movements of the forearm at the elbow joint.

Incorrect Options:

Trochlea (Option B):

  • The trochlea is a spool-shaped structure located on the distal end of the humerus bone, just medial to the capitulum.
  • It forms the trochlear notch of the ulna bone, creating the ulnohumeral joint.
  • The trochlea is responsible for the hinge-like movements of the elbow Joint, allowing flexion and extension of the forearm.

Olecranon (Option C):

  • The olecranon is a bony prominence located at the proximal end of the ulna bone, forming the bony tip of the elbow.
  • It serves as an attachment point for muscles and ligaments, including the triceps brachii muscle and the triceps tendon.
  • The olecranon helps stabilize the elbow joint and provides leverage for extension movements of the forearm.

Head of radius (Option D):

  • The head of the radius is the rounded, disc-shaped structure located at the proximal end of the radius bone.
  • It articulates with the capitulum of the humerus, forming the radiocapitular joint.
  • The head of the radius allows for rotation movements of the forearm, such as pronation and supination.

questions.text: Based on the clinical image below, what is the most probable nerve to be injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Long thoracic nerve

Explanation:

  • Injury to the long thoracic nerve results in weakness of the serratus anterior and winging of the scapula, as seen in the image.
  • The long thoracic nerve, from the upper part of the brachial plexus's superior trunk, usually receives contributions from cervical nerves C5, C6, and C7.
  • It innervates the serratus anterior muscle, weakness of which often causes scapular winging due to inadequate protraction countered by rhomboid and trapezius actions, leading to medial scapular winging.

Long thoracic nerve

Origin

C5 - C7

Insertion

Serratus anterior muscle, which is responsible for scapular protraction and upward rotation.

Nerve actions

(Motor function)
  • Protracts the scapula (pulls it forward around the thorax).
  • Assists in arm anteversion (moving the arm forward).
  • Lifts the ribs, aiding in respiration.
  • Responsible for the anterolateral motion of the scapula, which is necessary for arm elevation.

Incorrect Options:

Thoracodorsal nerve (Option A): mainly from C7 with contributions from C6 to C8, innervates the Latissimus dorsi muscle. It's often utilized as a nerve graft in surgeries.

Axillary nerve (Option B): arising from the brachial plexus's posterior cord, controls the teres minor, deltoid muscles, shoulder skin, and glenohumeral joint, often injured in orthopedic surgeries, shoulder dislocations, and rotator cuff tears.

Intercostal nerve (Option C): from T1 to T11 spinal nerves, provides sensory innervation to the chest wall and abdomen skin and motor innervation to intercostal and abdominalmuscles.

questions.text: Injury to the posterior interosseous nerve leads to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Loss of extension of digits

 

Explanation:

  • The posterior interosseous nerve (PIN) is a branch of the radial nerve, arising from the deep branch after passing through the supinator muscle.
  • It supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm except for the brachioradialis, extensor carpi radialis longus, and anconeus.
  • Injury to the PIN leads to inability to extend the fingers (digits) at the MCP joints while wrist extension is relatively preserved (due to intact ECRL).
  • Sensory function is not affected as the PIN is purely motor.

Posterior Interosseous Nerve Palsy

Feature

Description

Origin

Deep branch of radial nerve (after supinator)

Motor Supply

Extensor digitorum, extensor pollicis longus & brevis, extensor indicis, ECU

Sensory Supply

None (purely motor)

Clinical Features

Weak finger extension, wrist extension intact (via ECRL)

Common Causes

Radial tunnel syndrome, trauma, compression at the arcade of Frohse

 

Loss of extension of wrist (Option B): Incorrect because wrist extension is not completely lost, as the extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL) (innervated by the radial nerve before the PIN) is still functional.

Loss of supination (Option C): Incorrect because supination is mainly performed by the biceps brachii, with some contribution from the supinator (which is innervated by the PIN but has redundant function from the biceps).

Wrist drop (Option D): Incorrect because wrist drop occurs in a proximal radial nerve injury, affecting all extensors, while PIN lesions primarily affect finger extension with wrist extension relatively spared.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presents to the OPD complaining of pain in the medial part of the elbow for the past 4-6 weeks. He states that the pain worsens while lifting weights in the gym. On examination, there is tenderness over the medial epicondyle, and reverse Cozen's test is positive. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ulnar nerve

Explanation:

  • The patient suffers from medial epicondylitis or golfer's elbow. The Ulnar nerve is posterior to the medial epicondyle within the cubital tunnel.
  • The main symptom of medial epicondylitis is the 5 to 10 mm distal tenderness to the medial epicondyle.
  • The pain is generally aggravated with resisted wrist flexion and pronation, known as reverse Cozen's test.

Hand and Forearm Deformities:

  • Mallet Finger (Baseball Finger): Permanent flexion of the distal phalanx due to lateral band avulsion of the extensor tendon.
  • Boutonniere Deformity: Flexion of the middle phalanx and hyperextension of the distal phalanx due to central band avulsion of the extensor tendon.
  • Tennis Elbow (Lateral Epicondylitis): Inflammation of extensor tendons from the lateral epicondyle (common in tennis players, violinists).
  • Golfer’s Elbow (Medial Epicondylitis): Inflammation of flexor tendons from the medial epicondyle.
  • Volkmann Ischemic Contracture: Flexion deformity of fingers due to ischemic necrosis of forearm flexor muscles (e.g., tight cast injury).
  • Dupuytren Contracture: Progressive thickening of the palmar aponeurosis, pulling fingers into flexion.
  • Swan Neck Deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

Nerve

Root origin

Common causes

Features

Radial (Option C)

C5-T1
  • Compression in axilla (crutches, "Saturday night palsy")
  • Midshaft fracture of humerus
  • Repetitive pronation/supination (screwdriver use, "finger drop")

Above elbow injury:

  • Loss of sensation over posterior arm/forearm and dorsal hand
  • Wrist drop (loss of elbow, wrist, and finger extension)
  • Decreased grip strength (wrist extension necessary for maximal action of flexors)

Below elbow injury:

  • Distal paresthesias without wrist drop

Midshaft fracture:

  • Tricep function and posterior arm sensation spared

Median (Option A)

C5-T1
  • Supracondylar fracture of humerus (proximal lesion)
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome and wrist laceration (distal lesion)
  • "Ape hand" and "Hand of benediction"
  • Loss of wrist flexion
  • Loss of function of LOAF muscles (Lumbricals (lateral two), Opponens pollicis, Abductor pollicis brevis, Flexor pollicis brevis)
  • Loss of sensation over thenar eminence and dorsal and palmar aspects of lateral 3 1/2 fingers with proximal lesion

Ulnar

C8-T1
  • Fracture of medial epicondyle of humerus (proximal lesion)
  • Fractured hook of hamate (distal lesion) from fall on outstretched hand
  • Compression of nerve against hamate during cycling
  • "Ulnar claw" on digit extension
  • Radial deviation of wrist upon flexion (proximal lesion)
  • Decreased flexion of ulnar fingers
  • Loss of abduction and adduction of fingers (interossei)
  • Loss of thumb adduction
  • Loss of action of ulnar 2 lumbrical muscles
  • Loss of sensation over ulnar 1 1/2 fingers including hypothenar eminence

Axillary nerve injury (Option D): Would cause sensory loss over the lateral shoulder (regimental badge area), not the posterior forearm.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy came to the emergency room with the following X-ray. On examination, he had a sensory loss in the lateral arm and sensory loss in the posterior aspect of the forearm. Which of the following is true about his condition?

choices.text: Surgical neck humerus fracture with axillary nerve injury
Humerus shaft fracture with radial nerve palsy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Humerus shaft fracture with radial nerve palsy

Explanation:

  • The X-ray reveals a fracture in the shaft of the humerus, often accompanied by radial nerve damage, which affects wrist, finger, and thumb extension, along with sensation in the forearm and hand.
  • Clinical signs like sensory loss in the lateral arm and posterior forearm support this diagnosis, possibly due to trauma or compression from the fracture.

Nerve

Root origin

Common causes

Features

Radial

C5-T1
  • Compression in axilla (crutches, "Saturday night palsy")
  • Midshaft fracture of humerus
  • Repetitive pronation/supination (screwdriver use, "finger drop")

Above elbow injury:

  • Loss of sensation over posterior arm/forearm and dorsal hand
  • Wrist drop (loss of elbow, wrist, and finger extension)
  • Decreased grip strength (wrist extension necessary for maximal action of flexors)

Below elbow injury:

  • Distal paresthesias without wrist drop

Midshaft fracture:

  • Tricep function and posterior arm sensation spared

Median

C5-T1
  • Supracondylar fracture of humerus (proximal lesion)
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome and wrist laceration (distal lesion)
  • "Ape hand" and "Hand of benediction"
  • Loss of wrist flexion
  • Loss of function of LOAF muscles (Lumbricals (lateral two), Opponens pollicis, Abductor pollicis brevis, Flexor pollicis brevis)
  • Loss of sensation over thenar eminence and dorsal and palmar aspects of lateral 3 1/2 fingers with proximal lesion

Ulnar

C8-T1
  • Fracture of medial epicondyle of humerus (proximal lesion)
  • Fractured hook of hamate (distal lesion) from fall on outstretched hand
  • Compression of nerve against hamate during cycling
  • "Ulnar claw" on digit extension
  • Radial deviation of wrist upon flexion (proximal lesion)
  • Decreased flexion of ulnar fingers
  • Loss of abduction and adduction of fingers (interossei)
  • Loss of thumb adduction
  • Loss of action of ulnar 2 lumbrical muscles
  • Loss of sensation over ulnar 1 1/2 fingers including hypothenar eminence

 

Fracture-dislocation of the elbow (Option A): Typically affects the ulnar or median nerve, not the radial nerve.

Surgical neck humerus fracture with axillary nerve injury (Option B): Would cause sensory loss over the lateral shoulder (regimental badge area), not the posterior forearm.

Spine fracture with foot drop (Option C): Would involve the common peroneal nerve, leading to sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot and foot drop, which is unrelated to the current sensory findings.

questions.text: A man who was on crutches now presents with tingling and paraesthesia on the medial side of the arm, forearm, and hand. Which structure is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A

Explanation:

  • The patient has a history of using crutches, which can compress the Brachial plexus, indicated by A in the figure

Nerve

Root origin

Common causes

Features

Radial

C5-T1
  • Compression in axilla (crutches, "Saturday night palsy")
  • Midshaft fracture of humerus
  • Repetitive pronation/supination (screwdriver use, "finger drop")

Above elbow injury:

  • Loss of sensation over posterior arm/forearm and dorsal hand
  • Wrist drop (loss of elbow, wrist, and finger extension)
  • Decreased grip strength (wrist extension necessary for maximal action of flexors)

Below elbow injury:

  • Distal paresthesias without wrist drop

Midshaft fracture:

  • Tricep function and posterior arm sensation spared

Median

C5-T1
  • Supracondylar fracture of humerus (proximal lesion)
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome and wrist laceration (distal lesion)
  • "Ape hand" and "Hand of benediction"
  • Loss of wrist flexion
  • Loss of function of LOAF muscles (Lumbricals (lateral two), Opponens pollicis, Abductor pollicis brevis, Flexor pollicis brevis)
  • Loss of sensation over thenar eminence and dorsal and palmar aspects of lateral 3 1/2 fingers with proximal lesion

Ulnar

C8-T1
  • Fracture of medial epicondyle of humerus (proximal lesion)
  • Fractured hook of hamate (distal lesion) from fall on outstretched hand
  • Compression of nerve against hamate during cycling
  • "Ulnar claw" on digit extension
  • Radial deviation of wrist upon flexion (proximal lesion)
  • Decreased flexion of ulnar fingers
  • Loss of abduction and adduction of fingers (interossei)
  • Loss of thumb adduction
  • Loss of action of ulnar 2 lumbrical muscles
  • Loss of sensation over ulnar 1 1/2 fingers including hypothenar eminence

 

B (Option B):

  • The structure in the figure is a Subclavian artery
  • Compression would lead to vascular symptoms (cold, pale limb, weak pulses), not isolated tingling/paresthesia.

C (Option C):

  • The structure in the figure is a Subclavian Vein
  • Affected veins would cause swelling and venous congestion, not sensory loss.

D (Option D):

  • The structure in the figure is a Scalenus Anterior
  • While the scalene muscles can contribute to thoracic outlet syndrome, they mainly compress the subclavian vessels or brachial plexus at the root level, affecting more than just the medial arm.

questions.text: An injury to the shown area can lead to fracture of which bone?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Scaphoid:

  • The anatomical snuff box is a triangular-shaped depression on the dorsoradial aspect of the hand, and it's formed by the tendons of certain muscles. The scaphoid bone is an important player in this region.
  • The scaphoid bone is the most commonly fractured carpal bone, and a fall on the outstretched hand can lead to a fracture in the anatomical snuff box region.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lunate: The lunate is another carpal bone, but it's not typically associated with fractures in the anatomical snuff box.

Option C - Trapezium: The trapezium is also a carpal bone, but it's not commonly associated with fractures in the anatomical snuff box region.

Option D - Hamate: The hamate is located more towards the ulnar side of the hand and is not typically associated with fractures in the anatomical snuff box.

questions.text: Which muscle originates from medial epicondyle of humerus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pronator Teres:

  • This muscle originates from the medial epicondyle of the humerus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Supinator: It originates from the lateral epicondyle of the humerus.

Option C - Pronator Quadratus: This muscle originates from the distal part of the anterior ulna, not from the humerus.

Option D - Brachioradialis: It originates from the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus, not the medial epicondyle.

questions.text: A patient presents with hypothenar muscle wasting and loss of sensation of medial one and a half digits. Which of the following nerve is involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ulnar Nerve:

  • The hypothenar muscles and the sensation of the medial one and a half digits are innervated by the ulnar nerve. Damage to the ulnar nerve can result in these symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Median Nerve: The median nerve is responsible for innervating muscles in the anterior compartment of the forearm and the thenar muscles, not the hypothenar muscles.

Option C - Radial Nerve: The radial nerve primarily innervates the muscles of the posterior compartment of the arm and forearm. It's not associated with the symptoms described.

Option D - Musculocutaneous Nerve: This nerve innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm but is not involved in the symptoms described.

questions.text: Flexion, adduction, and medial rotation of arm is done by which muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pectoralis Major:

  • his muscle is responsible for flexion, adduction, and medial rotation of the arm at the shoulder joint. It's a key player in these movements.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pectoralis minor: This muscle is involved in stabilizing the scapula but doesn't play a significant role in the described movements.

Option C - Subclavius: The subclavius muscle helps stabilize and depress the clavicle but is not a prime mover for the described actions.

Option D - Serratus anterior: This muscle is more involved in protraction and upward rotation of the scapula, not the flexion, adduction, and medial rotation of the arm.

questions.text: At what level is the inferior scapular angle located?
questions.solution:
Correct option: D

  • Explanation: The inferior scapular angle is at the level of the seventh thoracic vertebra (T7).
  • The scapula, also known as the shoulder blade, is a flat triangular bone that is located on the posterior aspect of the thorax.
  • The inferior angle of the scapula is the lowermost point of the bone, and it lies at approximately the level of the eighth thoracic vertebra.

Incorrect option:

Option A. T2: The inferior scapular angle is not at the level of the second thoracic vertebra (T2). It is located at a lower level in the thoracic region.

Option B. T4: The inferior scapular angle is not at the level of the fourth thoracic vertebra (T4). It is located lower in the thoracic region.

Option C. T6: The inferior scapular angle is not at the level of the sixth thoracic vertebra (T6). It is located lower in the thoracic region.

questions.text: All of the following muscles are supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Flexor carpi ulnaris

Explanation:

The flexor carpi ulnaris (FCU) muscle is innervated by the muscular branches ulnar nerve.

The deep branch of the ulnar nerve is primarily responsible for innervating the majority of the intrinsic muscles of the hand. These include:

  • Hypothenar muscles: These are the muscles that form the fleshy prominence on the medial side of the palm (at the base of the little finger). They include:
    • Abductor digiti minimi (Option C)
    • Flexor digiti minimi brevis
    • Opponens digiti minimi
  • Lumbricals (medial two): Specifically, the 3rd and 4th lumbricals (Option A) (which act on the ring and little fingers). The lateral two lumbricals are supplied by the median nerve.
  • Interossei muscles: Both the:(Option B)
    • Dorsal interossei (four muscles that abduct the fingers)
    • Palmar interossei (three muscles that adduct the fingers)
  • Adductor pollicis: This powerful muscle is responsible for adduction of the thumb.
  • Flexor pollicis brevis (deep head): While the superficial head of the flexor pollicis brevis is supplied by the median nerve, the deep head typically receives innervation from the deep branch of the ulnar nerve.

questions.text: A man fell on his shoulder with his head pushed in the opposite direction. He presented with the following deformity. Which nerve root values are most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - C5 and C6:

Explanation:

  • A fall on the shoulder with the head pushed to the opposite side suggests a traction injury to the upper brachial plexus, resulting in the characteristic posture seen in Erb’s Palsy, most commonly affecting the C5 and C6 nerve roots.

Erb’s Palsy

Definition

Erb-Duchenne palsy results from damage to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (C5 and C6 nerve roots). (Option A)

Mechanism of Injury

Traction or stretching of the neck during childbirth (shoulder dystocia) or traumatic separation of the head and shoulder.

Anatomical Structures Involved

Brachial Plexus: Formed by ventral rami of C5-T1 spinal nerves

Upper Trunk: Union of C5 and C6 ventral rami

Erb’s Point: Located in the posterior triangle of the neck, where the upper trunk divides into anterior and posterior divisions.

Clinical Presentation
  • Muscle Weakness/ Paralysis
    • Shoulder Abduction: Affected (supraspinatus, deltoid)
    • External Rotation: Affected (infraspinatus, teres minor)
    • Elbow Flexion: Affected (biceps brachii, brachialis)
    • Forearm Supination: Affected (biceps brachii)
  • Arm Position: Limp arm by the side, forearm pronated, hand inward ("waiter’s tip" position).
  • Sensory Deficits: Numbness or tingling along the lateral arm, forearm, and hand, corresponding to C5 and C6 dermatomes.

Associated findings
  • Horner's Syndrome: Involvement of T1 nerve root, indicating a more extensive injury.
  • Skeletal abnormalities: Bone deformities (e.g., glenoid dysplasia, clavicular shortening) due to muscle imbalance.

Incorrect Options: 

  • C6 and C7 (Option B) involves the middle trunk of the brachial plexus, which is not typically affected by traction injuries from shoulder falls; it doesn't produce the classic Erb’s palsy posture.
  • C7 and C8 (Option C) affects the lower part of the brachial plexus, leading to deficits in wrist and finger movements rather than the shoulder and elbow posture characteristic of Erb’s palsy.
  • C8 and T1 (Option D) involves the lower trunk, typically injured by upward traction of the arm, resulting in Klumpke’s palsy with hand muscle weakness, not the upper limb findings seen here.

questions.text: A diabetic worker sustains a stab injury to the central region of his palm. After 3 days, he develops swelling, severe pain, and inability to extend his middle and ring fingers. Pus accumulation is suspected in one of the palmar spaces. Which of the following spaces is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - B:

Explanation:

  • A stab injury to the central palm in a diabetic patient, followed by swelling, pain, and inability to extend the middle and ring fingers, suggests pus accumulation in the midpalmar space (B) - a deep space bounded by the palmar aponeurosis and metacarpals, commonly involved in deep hand infections affecting the 3rd and 4th digits.

Incorrect Options:

  • Hypothenar space (Option A): Located on the ulnar side of the palm, involving the little finger - not the middle and ring fingers.
  • Thenar space (Option C): Found on the radial side of the palm, associated with the thumb and index finger, not the central palm.
  • Dorsal subaponeurotic space (Option D): Located on the dorsum of the hand, not the palm - not relevant in this scenario.

questions.text: During hyperextension, the long head of triceps gets detached from which site?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Infraglenoid tubercle

Explanation:

  • During hyperextension injuries, particularly with forceful backward arm movements as seen in overhead sports or trauma, the long head of the triceps may be stretched or avulsed from its origin at the infraglenoid tubercle.

Triceps Brachii

Origin

  • Long Head: Infraglenoid tubercle of the scapula
  • Lateral Head: Posterior surface of the humerus, above the radial (spiral) groove
  • Medial Head: Posterior surface of the humerus, below the radial (spiral) groove.

Insertion

  • Olecranon process of the ulna (3 heads insert via a common tendon)

Nerve supply
  • Radial nerve (C6, C7, C8)
  • Medial head often receives branches directly in the axilla.

Function

  • Primary extensor of the forearm at the elbow joint
  • Shoulder extension and adduction

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Supraglenoid tubercle: Origin of the long head of the biceps brachii, not triceps.

Option C - Shaft of humerus: Gives origin to the lateral and medial heads of the triceps, not the long head.

Option D - Olecranon process: This is the insertion point of all three heads of the triceps, not the origin.

questions.text: A 25 year old male presented with symptoms of inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4 th and 5 th digits. He was also not able to hold a piece of paper between his fingers. What is the likely site of injury?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with:

  • Inability to flex the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints of the 4th and 5th digits
  • Weakness in finger adduction, causing difficulty in holding a piece of paper (Froment’s sign positive)

These findings suggest ulnar nerve injury affecting the medial half of flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) and intrinsic hand muscles, which occurs at the level of the medial epicondyle (cubital tunnel syndrome).

Ulnar Nerve Injuries by Site

Site of Injury

Common Causes

Clinical Features

Key Signs

Brachial Plexus (C8-T1 roots)

Trauma, birth injury (Klumpke’s palsy)

Weakness in intrinsic hand muscles, forearm flexors, ± Horner’s syndrome

Claw hand, sensory loss in medial forearm/hand

Cubital Tunnel (Elbow)

Compression at medial epicondyle, prolonged flexion, trauma

Weak grip, hypothenar atrophy, numbness in 4th/5th digits

Positive Tinel’s at elbow, Froment’s sign

Guyon’s Canal (Wrist)

Cyclists, repetitive trauma (handlebar palsy)

Weak finger abduction/adduction, intrinsic muscle weakness

No dorsal hand sensory loss, claw hand more pronounced

Distal Ulnar Nerve (Hand)

Lacerations, trauma

Isolated intrinsic hand weakness, claw hand

Froment’s sign, Wartenberg’s sign

Shaft of Humerus (Option A): Incorrect because it affects the radial nerve, leading to wrist drop but not ulnar nerve dysfunction.

Lateral Epicondyle (Option B): Incorrect because it affects the radial nerve and leads to weak wrist and finger extension (tennis elbow).

Neck of Humerus (Option D): Incorrect because it affects the axillary nerve, leading to deltoid muscle weakness and loss of sensation over the lateral shoulder.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with tingling sensation of lateral 3 digits with loss of sensation of base of thumb on the dorsal aspect of the hand. Which is the nerve involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Radial nerve

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with:
     
    • Tingling of lateral 3 digits
       
    • Loss of sensation at the base (root) of the thumb on the dorsal aspect
       
  • These findings are best explained by involvement of the superficial branch of the radial nerve, which provides:
     
    • Cutaneous sensation to the dorsum of the hand, especially the base of the thumb and proximal parts of the lateral 3½ fingers, excluding the fingertips.
       
  • The tingling in the dorsal aspect of the lateral 3 digits may also be due to involvement of the proximal dorsal hand region, which is supplied by the radial nerve, not the median nerve.
     
  • The median nerve supplies the palmar aspect and the distal dorsal phalanges (fingertips) of the lateral 3½ digits, not the base of the thumb dorsally.
     

Sensory Supply of the Dorsal and Ventral Aspects of the Palm and Fingers:

Region

Nerve

Area Supplied

Ventral (Palmar) Aspect

Lateral 3½ fingers + lateral palm

Median nerve

Palmar surface of thumb, index, middle, and lateral half of ring finger + palm

Medial 1½ fingers + medial palm

Ulnar nerve

Palmar surface of little finger and medial half of ring finger + palm

Thenar eminence (skin)

Median nerve

Over the base of thumb (root of thumb, palmar side)

Hypothenar eminence

Ulnar nerve

Over the base of little finger

Dorsal Aspect

Lateral 3½ fingertips (nail beds)

Median nerve

Dorsal distal phalanges of thumb, index, middle, and lateral ring finger

Medial 2½ fingers + hand dorsum

Ulnar nerve

Dorsal aspect of little finger, medial half of ring finger, and medial hand

Lateral 1½ dorsum + web space

Radial nerve

Dorsum of hand near base of thumb, lateral hand, and 1st web space

Root (base) of thumb

Radial nerve

Dorsal aspect of thumb base and adjacent dorsum of hand



 

 

Ulnar nerve (Option B): Incorrect. Supplies the medial 1½ digits, which are not involved in this case.
 

Median nerve (Option C): Incorrect. Supplies palmar aspect and distal dorsal fingertips of lateral 3½ digits. It does not supply the dorsal root of the thumb, which is involved here.
 

AIN (Option D): Incorrect. Purely motor nerve. No cutaneous distribution.

questions.text: In the given image, the tendon marked by the arrow is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Flexor carpi radialis

Explanation:

  • The above-marked structure in the diagram is Flexor carpi radialis as it is present on the radial side of the forearm.
  • Flexor carpi radialis originates from the medial epicondyle of the humerus and inserts into the bases of the second and third metacarpal bones.

Muscles of Forearm:

  • Superficial flexor muscles: Origin, insertion, nerve supply and action:

Muscles

Origin

Insertion

Nerve supply

Action

Pronator teres

Humeral head - medial supracondylar ridge and from ulna

Middle of radius

Median nerve

Pronation and weak flexor of forearm

Flexor carpi radialis

Medial epicondyle of humerus

Base of  2nd /3rd metacarpal bones

Median nerve

Weak flexor and abducts (radial deviation)the wrist

Palmaris longus

Medial epicondyle of humerus

Palmar aponeurosis and flexor retinaculum

Median nerve

Weak flexor of wrist

Flexor carpi ulnaris

Medial epicondyle of humerus and medial olecranon and posterior border of ulna

Pisiform bone and hook of hamate and 5th metacarpal

Ulnar nerve

Weak flexor and adducts (ulnar deviation)the wrist

Flexor digitorum superficialis

Medial epicondyle of humerus, coronoid process, oblique line of radius

Divides into 4 tendons and insert to middle phalanx

Median nerve

Flex the wrist, metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joint

 

  • Deep flexor muscles–origin, insertion, nerve supply and action

Muscles

Origin

Insertion

Nerve supply

Action

Flexor digitorum profundus

Anteromedial surface of ulna and interosseous membrane

Divided into 4 tendons and Distal phalanx

Anterior interosseous nerve and ulnar nerve

Flex the wrist, metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joint and distal interphalangeal joint

Flexor pollicis longus

Anterior surface of radius and interosseous membrane and coronoid process

Distal phalanx of thumb

Anterior interosseous nerve

Flex the wrist and interphalangeal joint of wrist

Pronator quadratus

Anterior surface of distal ulna

Anterior surface of distal Radius

Anterior interosseous nerve

Pronates forearm

questions.text: A road traffic accident patient has presented to you with features of a nerve injury involving right upper limb. On examination, the patient is able to carry out flexion at metacarpo-phalangeal joint and extension at interphalangeal joint. The most likely nerve involved is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Radial nerve

Explanation:

  • The most likely nerve involved is the posterior interosseous nerve, which is a branch of the radial nerve.
  • The lumbricals and interossei can carry out flexion at MCP and extension at IP joints.

Features of Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN) Palsy:

(a branch of the radial nerve)

  • Wrist extension not affected because extensor carpi radialis longus and brevis are supplied by the radial nerve.
  • Only one extension lost in PIN is extension at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint. So, the patient has finger drop, not wrist drop.
  • No sensory loss, because it is a motor nerve.
  • common in Monteggia fracture dislocation

Median nerve & Ulnar nerve (Options A & C):

  • They supply the lumbricals and interossei, which are involved in flexion at metacarpophalangeal joint and extension at the interphalangeal joint
  • Since these actions are present, these nerves are intact

Anterior interosseous nerve (Options B):

  • The anterior interosseous nerve supplies the Flexor Digitorum Profundus muscle and involved in the flexion and extension of the index and middle finger.
  • Since the flexion of all the fingers is intact, this nerve is intact.

questions.text: A patient presents with abnormal sensations in the little finger and part of the ring finger with weakness of the hand. Also, there is a loss of coordination in the fingers. What is the nerve injured in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ulnar nerve

Explanation:

  • The ulnar nerve supplies all the intrinsic muscles of the hand except the thenar muscles and lateral two lumbricals and is responsible for the sensations of the medial 11½ fingers of the hand.
  • Hence abnormal sensations in the little finger and part of the ring finger with weakness on the palm side would be due to the ulnar nerve injury.

Damage to the ulnar nerve leads to:

  • Difficulty in flexing the fourth and fifth fingers due to paralysis of the flexor digitorum profundus (medial part) and the lumbricals (3rd and 4th).
  • Inability to adduct the thumb, as the adductor pollicis is also innervated by the ulnar nerve.

Motor branches of Ulnar nerve:

Ulnar nerve (C7, C8 & T1- root values)

Muscle

Action

Anterior Forearm
  • Flexor carpi ulnaris
  • Medial half of flexor digitorum profundus
  • Flexion and adduction of hand at wrist
  • Flexion of distal phalanges.

Hand
  • Hypothenar muscles
  • Abducts little finger
  • Flexes little finger
  • Pulls fifth metacarpal forward as in cupping the palm
  • 8 Interossei muscles
    • Palmar Interossei
    • Dorsal Interossei
  • Adducts digits 2-5 (Mnemonic PAD)
  • Abduct digits 2-5 (Mnemonic DAB)
  • Assists Lumbricals in MCP flexion and IP extension of digits 2-5

Lumbricals of Digits 4 & 5
  • Flexion of MCP
  • Extension of PIP & DIP joints of digits 4 and 5
  • Adductor pollicis

Adduction the thumb

Ulnar nerve supply

 

Radial nerve (Option B): The radial nerve injury is characterised by wrist drop and does not cause the symptoms mentioned in this case.

Median nerve (Option C): the median nerve supplies the thenar muscles and is responsible for sensations on the medial side of the index finger, middle finger, and lateral side of the ring finger.

Axillary nerve (Option D): Responsible for the nerve supply of the deltoid muscle in the shoulder region.

questions.text: A patient is referred to a higher center with the diagnosis of fracture. On examination, the forearm pulses were not palpable. An upper arm X-ray was done, which is given below. Which artery is most likely to be injured in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Brachial artery

Explanation:

  • The brachial artery is a major artery in the upper arm and runs along the anterior aspect of the upper arm. It is the main blood vessel that supplies blood to the arm. The brachial artery divides into the radial and ulnar arteries in the elbow region.
  • An injury to the brachial artery can result in reduced blood flow to the entire arm, including the forearm and hand. This can cause a reduction or absence of pulses in the upper arm.

Radial artery (Option A): While an injury to the radial artery can result in reduced blood flow to the lateral aspect of the forearm and hand, it would not affect the pulses in the upper arm.

Ulnar artery (Option B): Like the radial artery, an injury to the ulnar artery can result in reduced blood flow to the medial aspect of the forearm and hand but would not affect the pulses in the upper arm.

Anterior interosseous artery (Option D): An injury to the anterior interosseous artery can result in reduced blood flow to the muscles in the anterior compartment of the forearm but would not affect the pulses in the upper arm.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient after an injury presented with a deformity as shown in the image. Which nerve will be damaged in the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Radial Nerve

Explanation:

  • In the given scenario, the image displaying wrist drop and a fracture of the shaft of the humerus is indicative of damage to the radial nerve

Nerve

Root origin

Common causes

Features

Radial

C5-T1
  • Compression in axilla (crutches, "Saturday night palsy")
  • Midshaft fracture of humerus
  • Repetitive pronation/supination (screwdriver use, "finger drop")

Above elbow injury:

  • Loss of sensation over posterior arm/forearm and dorsal hand
  • Wrist drop (loss of elbow, wrist, and finger extension)
  • Decreased grip strength (wrist extension necessary for maximal action of flexors)

Below elbow injury:

  • Distal paresthesias without wrist drop

Midshaft fracture:

  • Tricep function and posterior arm sensation spared

 

Ulnar Nerve (Option A): The ulnar nerve mainly innervates forearm and hand muscles for wrist flexion and finger abduction. It's not typically involved in wrist drop.

Median Nerve (Option C): The median nerve innervates specific forearm muscles and the hand's anterior compartment but isn't heavily involved in wrist extension, the main problem in the image.

Musculocutaneous Nerve (Option D): The musculocutaneous nerve mainly innervates the anterior arm muscles, like the biceps brachii, aiding in elbow flexion, not wrist extension.

questions.text: Which bone is most likely to be fractured in an injury to the anatomical snuff box?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Scaphoid

Explanation:

  • The anatomical snuff box is a triangular depression located on the radial aspect of the dorsum (back) of the hand.
  • It is formed by the tendons of the extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis muscles.
  • Fractures within the anatomical snuff box are commonly associated with falls onto an outstretched hand, particularly with the wrist extended.
  • The most fractured bone in this region is the scaphoid bone, also known as the navicular bone.

Anatomical snuff box/Radial fossa: Triangular hollow visible on the lateral aspect of the wrist when the thumb is fully extended.

Boundaries:

  • Anterolateral: Extensor pollicis brevis, Abductor pollicis longus
  • Posteromedial: Extensor pollicis longus
  • Roof:
    • Dorsal cutaneous branch of radial nerve: Found in the skin and subcutaneous tissue of anatomical snuff box.
    • Cephalic vein: Arises from dorsal venous network of hand and crosses anatomical snuff box to travel to the anterolateral aspect of forearm.

Contents

  • Radial Artery: Crosses the floor of the anatomical snuff box.

Tenderness in the anatomical snuff box following a fall on an outstretched hand strongly suggests a scaphoid fracture, as the scaphoid bone lies in the floor of the anatomical snuff box. This type of fracture is common and can have complications due to poor blood supply.

 

Lunar (lunate) bone (Option B):  The lunate bone, found in the wrist joint, rarely fractures in injuries to the anatomical snuff box and isn't usually part of its formation.

Cuboid bone (Option C): The cuboid bone is one of the tarsal bones located in the foot. It is not related to the anatomical snuff box or the wrist region.

Trapezius (Option D): The trapezius is a large muscle located in the upper back and neck area. It is not a bone and is not related to the anatomical snuff box or wrist injuries.

questions.text: A patient who has taken the first COVID vaccine comes for the second dose. An astute nurse noticed that the shoulder was flabby, flat, and was asymmetrical. There was an associated loss of contour of the shoulder joint. Injury to which of the structures might have resulted and was avoidable?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Axillary nerve

Explanation:

  • The axillary nerve (C5-C6) is vulnerable to injury during intramuscular injections in the deltoid muscle, especially if injected too low or too deep.
  • Injury results in:
    • Flattening of the shoulder (loss of deltoid muscle bulk).
    • Loss of shoulder contour (due to deltoid atrophy).
    • Weakness in abduction beyond 15° (deltoid function loss).
    • Sensory loss over the lateral shoulder (regimental badge area).
  • Prevention: Intramuscular injections should be given in the upper lateral quadrant of the deltoid to avoid axillary nerve injury.

Axillary Nerve Injury

Aspect

Details

Origin

Arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus (C5-C6).

Course

Passes through quadrangular space with the posterior circumflex humeral artery.

Motor Supply

Deltoid muscle (shoulder abduction) and teres minor (external rotation).

Sensory Supply

Skin over the lateral shoulder (regimental badge area) via the superior lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm.

Common Causes of Injury

Improper intramuscular injection, shoulder dislocation, humeral surgical neck fracture.

Clinical Features

Shoulder atrophy, loss of contour, weakness in abduction, and sensory loss over the deltoid region.

 

 

Rotator cuff (Option A) - Incorrect: Involved in shoulder stability but does not cause loss of shoulder contour when injured.

Posterior circumflex artery (Option B) - Incorrect: Runs with the axillary nerve but its injury would cause vascular compromise, not motor weakness.

Lateral cutaneous nerve of arm (Option C) - Incorrect: Only provides sensory innervation; it does not affect shoulder shape or movement.

questions.text: Which nerve is affected in a 50-year-old male who has a positive Trendelenburg test on the right side?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Right superior gluteal nerve

 

Explanation:

A positive Trendelenburg test indicates weakness of the hip abductors, specifically the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus.

 

These muscles are innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. In this case, the right-sided Trendelenburg sign means the right gluteus medius and minimus are weak, which occurs due to damage to the right superior gluteal nerve.

 

Trendelenberg sign:

  • When the body's weight is balanced on one leg, the gluteal muscles on the supported side help elevate the opposite, unsupported side of the pelvis.
  • However, if there is a malfunction in the abductor mechanism, the Sound side sinks, which is referred to as a positive Trendelenburg sign (uncompensated).
  • This sign indicates issues with hip abductors, such as paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus; problems with the fulcrum, including congenital or pathological hip dislocations; and concerns related to body weight, such as an unhealed fracture of the femoral neck.
  • When patients with the gluteus medius and minimus paralysis walk, they have a characteristic lurching gait ie, during the single leg supporting phase of walking, there is leaning of the trunk to the affected side known as the compensated Trendelenburg sign.
  • Duck waddling gait is seen when both the sides are affected.

 

 

Right inferior gluteal nerve (option A): The inferior gluteal nerve innervates the gluteus maximus, which is responsible for hip extension, not abduction. Damage here would cause difficulty rising from a seated position or climbing stairs, not a Trendelenburg sign.

 

Left superior gluteal nerve (option C): If the left superior gluteal nerve were affected, the right hip would drop when standing on the left leg, not the right leg.

 

Left inferior gluteal nerve (option D): The inferior gluteal nerve does not control hip abduction, and the left-sided nerve would not cause a right-sided Trendelenburg sign.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Median nerve

 

Explanation:

The 1st lumbrical is primarily innervated by the median nerve. The first lumbrical is located in the hand, and it helps in flexing the metacarpophalangeal joint and extending the interphalangeal joints. It is innervated by the median nerve, which supplies the lumbricals 1 and 2 (the first two lumbricals).

 

  • The median nerve, which innervates the muscles responsible for thumb abduction and opposition, is formed from the anterior rami of spinal nerves C5 to T1, derived from the brachial plexus.
  • It primarily supplies the anterior forearm muscles and the thenar eminence of the hand, which includes:
    • Muscles of the Thenar eminence:
      • Abductor Pollicis Brevis: Responsible for thumb abduction.
      • Flexor Pollicis Brevis: Assists in thumb flexion.
      • Opponens Pollicis: Enables opposition of the thumb.
    • Lumbricals (Lateral 2): Responsible for flexion at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and extension at the interphalangeal (IP) joints of the 2nd and 3rd digits

 

  • Sensory supply: Lateral 3 1⁄2 digits in the palmar aspect & tip of same digits on the dorsum.

.

Brachial Plexus: The brachial plexus is a network of nerves formed by the anterior rami of the lower four cervical nerves (C5, C6, C7, C8) and the first thoracic nerve (T1)

  • Components of the Brachial Plexus:
    • Roots: Five roots (C5 to T1), deep to the scalenus anterior muscle.
    • Trunks: Upper trunk: C5 and C6, Middle trunk: C7, Lower trunk: C8 and T1
    • Divisions: Located behind the clavicle.
    • Cords: Three cords form from the divisions
      • Lateral cord: Anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunks.
      • Medial cord: Anterior division of the lower trunk.
      • Posterior cord: Posterior divisions of all three trunks.


 

Branches:

From Roots
  • Long thoracic nerve (C5, C6, C7)
  • Dorsal scapular nerve (C5)

From Trunks
  • Suprascapular nerve (C5, C6)
  • Nerve to subclavius (C5, C6)

Lateral Cord
  • Lateral pectoral nerve (C5, C6, C7)
  • Lateral root of median nerve (C5, C6, C7)
  • Musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6, C7)

Medial Cord
  • Medial pectoral nerve (C8, T1)
  • Medial cutaneous nerve of arm (C8, T1)
  • Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm (C8, T1)
  • Medial root of median nerve (C8, T1)
  • Ulnar nerve (C7, C8, T1)

Posterior Cord
  • Radial nerve (C5, C6, C7, C8, T1)
  • Axillary nerve (C5, C6)
  • Thoraco-dorsal nerve (C6, C7, C8)
  • Upper subscapular nerve (C5, C6)
  • Lower subscapular nerve (C5, C6)



 

Radial nerve (option A): The radial nerve innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm and hand, not the lumbricals, which are responsible for flexion and extension of the fingers.

 

Ulnar nerve (option C): The ulnar nerve innervates the lumbricals 3 and 4 (the last two lumbricals), not the first lumbrical.

 

Musculocutaneous nerve (option D): The musculocutaneous nerve primarily innervates the flexor muscles of the upper arm (e.g., biceps brachii), not the lumbricals of the hand.

questions.text: A patient with leprosy presented with the deformity as shown below. Which nerve injury causes the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ulnar nerve

Explanation:

  • The image shows "claw hand deformity", which is characteristic of ulnar nerve injury.
  • The deformity results from paralysis of the lumbricals (which flex the MCP joints and extend the IP joints of the 4th and 5th fingers).
  • The 4th and 5th fingers are hyperextended at the MCP joints and flexed at the IP joints, leading to a claw-like appearance.
  • Common causes in leprosy: Ulnar nerve involvement due to nerve infiltration and fibrosis, leading to motor impairment.

Ulnar Nerve Palsy and Claw Hand

Feature

Ulnar Nerve Palsy (Claw Hand)

Affected Muscles

Lumbricals (3rd & 4th), Interossei, Hypothenar muscles

Deficit Seen

MCP hyperextension, IP flexion (mainly in 4th & 5th fingers)

Common Causes

Leprosy, trauma at the elbow (cubital tunnel) or wrist (Guyon's canal)

Tests for Ulnar Nerve

Froment’s sign (weak adductor pollicis)

Treatment

Physiotherapy, nerve grafting, claw correction surgery

 

Radial nerve (Option B): Incorrect because its injury causes wrist drop, not claw hand.

Median nerve (Option C): Incorrect because it causes ape hand deformity (loss of thumb opposition).

Posterior interosseous nerve (Option D): Incorrect because it affects finger extension, leading to finger drop, not claw hand.

questions.text: Injury of the lower brachial plexus leads to Klumpke’s paralysis. What is the characteristic clinical finding seen in this lesion?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Claw hand

 

Explanation:

Klumpke's paralysis occurs due to injury of the lower brachial plexus (C8-T1), which affects the intrinsic muscles of the hand, particularly the lumbricals, interossei, and thenar/hypothenar muscles. This results in "claw hand", where there is hyperextension of the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion of the interphalangeal joints, leading to a characteristic clawed appearance of the fingers.

Klumpke’s Paralysis

 

Aspect

Details

Site of Injury

Lower trunk of the brachial plexus

Cause of Injury

Undue arm abduction (e.g., clutching after a fall)

Birth injury

Nerve Roots Involved

Primarily T1, partially C8

Muscles Affected

  • Intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1)
  • Ulnar flexors of the wrist and fingers (C8)

Hand Deformity

  • Claw hand: unopposed action of long flexors and extensors
    • Hyperextension at metacarpophalangeal joints
    • Flexion at interphalangeal joints

Disabilities Associated

  • Complete claw hand
  • Cutaneous anesthesia and analgesia along the ulnar border of forearm and hand
  • Horner’s Syndrome (if T1 injured near sympathetic ganglion)
    • Symptoms: ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis, enophthalmos, loss of ciliospinal reflex
  • Vasomotor Changes
    • Warmer, drier skin in the sensory loss area due to arteriolar dilation and lack of sweating
  • Trophic Changes
    • Long-term paralysis results in dry, scaly skin, brittle nails, and atrophy of finger pulp



 

Horner’s syndrome is also associated with lower brachial plexus injuries but is not the primary clinical finding.

Policeman tip hand (option A): This is a sign of upper brachial plexus injury (C5-C6), typically resulting in waiter's tip position due to paralysis of the deltoid, biceps, and brachioradialis.

 

Wrist drop (option B): This is a feature of radial nerve injury, leading to the inability to extend the wrist and fingers. It is not a characteristic finding in Klumpke’s paralysis.

 

Horner’s syndrome (option D) can occur in lower brachial plexus injury due to sympathetic fiber disruption, leading to ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the same side. While present, it is not the primary clinical feature of Klumpke's paralysis.

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of chop injury to the right hand is undergoing surgical repairs . It is observed that the patient is unable to completely fold the right ring finger, while making the fist , which structure injury results in this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Flexor digitorum profundus

Explanation:

  • The flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) is responsible for flexion at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints of the medial four fingers.
  • If the FDP to the ring finger is injured, the patient will be unable to fully flex the ring finger when making a fist.

Muscles Involved in the Movement of Interphalangeal Joints

The interphalangeal (IP) joints include:

  1. Proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints – between proximal and middle phalanges.
  2. Distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints – between middle and distal phalanges.

Movement

Muscles Involved

Innervation

Flexion of PIP joints

Flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS)

Median nerve

Flexion of DIP joints

Flexor digitorum profundus (FDP)

Lateral part (index & middle fingers): Median nerve

Medial part (ring & little fingers): Ulnar nerve

Extension of PIP & DIP joints

Extensor digitorum

Extensor indicis (index finger only)

Extensor digiti minimi (little finger only)

Radial nerve (posterior interosseous branch)

Assists in extension of PIP & DIP joints

Lumbricals

Palmar & dorsal interossei

Lumbricals: Lateral 2 (median nerve), medial 2 (ulnar nerve)

Interossei: Ulnar nerve

 

Median nerve (Option A): Incorrect because median nerve injury would affect multiple fingers (thumb, index, middle), not just the ring finger alone.

Flexor retinaculum (Option B): Incorrect because injury to the retinaculum leads to carpal tunnel syndrome, affecting the median nerve distribution, not isolated finger flexion.

Flexor pollicis longus (Option D): Incorrect because this muscle only flexes the thumb, not the ring finger.

questions.text: Biceps brachii functions as which type of muscle for lifting the forearm ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Primary mover

Explanation:

The biceps brachii is the primary mover (agonist) for forearm flexion at the elbow joint. When lifting the forearm, it contracts to generate movement by pulling the radius upward.

Muscle Roles in Movement

Term

Definition

Example in Forearm Flexion

Primary Mover (Agonist)

Main muscle responsible for movement.

Biceps brachii flexes the elbow.

Antagonist

Muscle that opposes the primary mover.

Triceps brachii extends the elbow, opposing the biceps.

Synergist

Assists the primary mover by adding force or stability.

Brachialis helps the biceps in flexion.

Fixator

Stabilizes the origin of the primary mover.

Rotator cuff muscles stabilize the shoulder joint during flexion.

Synergistic (Option A): Incorrect because the brachialis acts as a synergist, not the biceps brachii.

Fixator (Option B): Incorrect because fixators stabilize joints, like the rotator cuff stabilizing the shoulder.

Antagonist (Option C): Incorrect because the triceps brachii is the antagonist, opposing biceps action.

questions.text: All of the following take part in the formation of the wrist joint, except:-
questions.solution:
Correct Option D:

  • Distal end of ulna: The distal end of the ulna does not directly participate in the formation of the wrist joint. Instead, it forms the ulnar styloid process, which provides attachment for ligaments and provides stability to the wrist joint. The ulna primarily articulates with the radius at the distal radioulnar joint, which is separate from the wrist joint itself.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Scaphoid: The scaphoid bone, a carpal bone of the wrist, articulates with the distal radius, crucial for wrist joint formation.

Option B: Triquetrum: The triquetrum is another carpal bone that participates in the formation of the wrist joint. It articulates with the distal end of the ulna and the lunate bone.

Option C:Distal end of radius: The radial articular surface at the end of the radius is vital for the wrist joint, connecting with carpal bones like the scaphoid and lunate.

questions.text: Loss of flexion at the interphalangeal joint of thumb after supracondylar fracture is due to the involvement of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D.

Loss of flexion at the interphalangeal joint of the thumb after a supracondylar fracture is due to anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) involvement. AIN, a branch of the median nerve in the forearm, innervates deep flexor muscles, including the flexor pollicis longus responsible for thumb flexion. With a supracondylar humerus fracture, AIN compression or injury can weaken or paralyze the flexor pollicis longus, causing thumb joint flexion inability.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Deep branch of ulnar nerve: The deep branch of the ulnar nerve innervates the hypothenar eminence and intrinsic hand muscles, not thumb interphalangeal joint flexion.

Option B. Median nerve: Median nerve injury typically leads to a broader pattern of motor and sensory deficits in the hand.

Option C. Posterior interosseous nerve: The posterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the radial nerve, mainly innervates extensor muscles in the forearm and doesn't play a direct role in thumb flexion.

questions.text: What are the effects of a Supracondylar fracture ?

choices.text: Loss of sensation of the nail of index finger
Loss of sensation at the tip of radial tubercle
Loss of sensation of the 4th interdigital cleft

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A. Loss of sensation of the nail of the index finger: Ape thumb deformity; Benediction hand; Weakness in wrist flexion; hand deviates to ulnar side on flexion; flexion of index and middle finger is lost; anterior abduction, opposition and flexion of thumb is compromised; sensory loss on the lateral 3 & ½ fingers; difficulty in making an 'O' with thumb and index finger.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option B. Hypothenar muscles wasting: Lesion of the median nerve wouldn't directly cause wasting or weakness of the hypothenar muscles, as they're innervated by the ulnar nerve, not the median nerve.

Option C. Loss of sensation at the tip of the radial tubercle: A median nerve lesion wouldn't cause loss of sensation at the radial tubercle tip, as its innervation comes from radial nerve branches, not the median nerve.

Option D. Loss of sensation of the 4th interdigital cleft: A median nerve lesion wouldn't lead to sensory loss in the 4th interdigital cleft since its innervation comes from the ulnar nerve, not the median nerve.

questions.text: One of the nerves supplying the upper limb, the upper lateral cutaneous nerve of arm, supplying the skin overlying the posterior border of the deltoid muscle as well as covering the long head of the triceps, is a branch of:
questions.solution:
Correct option: D

  • The axillary nerve provides sensory innervation to the skin overlying the posterior border of the deltoid muscle and extends down to cover the long head of the triceps muscle.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Musculocutaneous nerve: This nerve supplies motor innervation to the anterior compartment muscles of the arm and does not supply the mentioned sensory area.

Option B. Radial nerve: The radial nerve supplies sensory innervation to the posterior aspect of the arm but does not specifically provide innervation to the mentioned area.

Option C. Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve primarily supplies sensory innervation to the medial aspect of the hand and does not innervate the mentioned area.

questions.text: Which finger possesses two dorsal interossei muscles among the following options?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: The middle finger has two dorsal interossei muscles.

The dorsal interossei muscles are a group of muscles located in the hand between the metacarpal bones. They play a role in finger abduction, which is the movement of the fingers away from the midline of the hand. The middle finger is the only finger that has two dorsal interossei muscles.

Incorrect Option:

Option A: The index finger has only one dorsal interosseous muscle.

Option B: The little finger, also known as the Pinky finger, has only one dorsal interosseous muscle.

Option D: The ring finger has only one dorsal interosseous muscle.

questions.text: What is the function of the muscle marked as A in the image below, at the metacarpophalangeal joint?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Flexion

  • The lumbrical muscles, marked as A in the image, play a role in flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joint.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Extension: Extension straightens or widens the angle between bones. Lumbrical muscles don't aid in extending the metacarpophalangeal joint.

Option C. Adduction: In the metacarpophalangeal joint, adduction brings fingers closer together. Lumbrical muscles aren't involved in adduction.

Option D. Abduction: At the metacarpophalangeal joint, abduction spreads fingers apart. Lumbrical muscles aren't involved in abduction.

questions.text: Which of the statements below accurately describes De Quervain's tenosynovitis?

choices.text: Fingers are held in mild extension
Most common involvement is index finger

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: It affects APL and EPB: This statement is correct. De Quervain's tenosynovitis specifically affects the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus (APL) and extensor pollicis brevis (EPB). These tendons run along the thumb side of the wrist and are responsible for thumb movement

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Fingers are held in mild extension: This is incorrect. In De Quervain's tenosynovitis, the affected fingers are typically flexed, not extended.

Option C: Most common involvement is index finger: This is incorrect. De Quervain's tenosynovitis mainly affects the thumb side of the wrist, involving the tendons of APL and EPB, and doesn't usually involve the index finger.

Option D: Treatment is surgery: This is incorrect. Surgery isn't usually the first treatment for De Quervain's tenosynovitis. Initially, conservative measures like rest, splinting, anti-inflammatory medication, and physical therapy are attempted.

questions.text: Nerve supply of the area marked by arrow in the image is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option :

Option A: Radial nerve: The radial nerve supplies the area marked by the arrow in the image, which corresponds to the anatomical snuff box. The anatomical snuff box is located on the dorsum (back) of the hand and is formed by tendons of the extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis muscles. The radial nerve provides sensory innervation to this area.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Posterior interosseous nerve: The posterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the radial nerve that supplies the deep extensor muscles of the forearm. It does not directly innervate the area marked in the image.

Option C: Median nerve: The median nerve primarily supplies the palmar aspect of the hand, including the thenar muscles and lateral 3 and a half digits. It does not directly supply the area marked in the image.

Option D: Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve primarily innervates the medial aspect of the hand, including the hypothenar muscles and the ulnar side of the palm. It does not directly supply the area marked in the image.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: Median nerve: The median nerve is the correct answer. It provides motor innervation to the lumbrical muscles of the hand, including the 2nd lumbrical. The lumbrical muscles are responsible for flexing the metacarpophalangeal joints and extending the interphalangeal joints of the fingers.

Incorrect Options :

Option A: Posterior interosseous nerve: The posterior interosseous nerve primarily supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm. It does not supply the structure marked in the image, which is the 2nd lumbrical.

Option C: Anterior interosseous nerve: The anterior interosseous nerve supplies the deep flexor muscles of the forearm, but it does not directly innervate the lumbrical muscles.

Option D: Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve innervates the muscles of the hypothenar eminence, interosseous muscles, and intrinsic muscles of the hand. It does not directly supply the 2nd lumbrical muscle.

questions.text: The arrow in the image denotes which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Extensor carpi radialis: The image shows the extensor carpi radialis muscle, which is indicated by the arrow. This muscle is located in the forearm and plays a role in extending and abducting the wrist.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Brachioradialis: The arrow in the image doesn't point to the brachioradialis muscle, which is located in the forearm but positioned more laterally compared to the extensor carpi radialis.

Option C: Supinator: The arrow in the image doesn't point to the supinator muscle, situated in the forearm, assisting in forearm supination by rotating the palm upward.

Option D: Flexor carpi radialis brevis: The arrow in the image doesn't indicate the flexor carpi radialis, a muscle responsible for wrist flexion.radialis brevis." The correct name for the muscle associated with flexing the wrist is the flexor carpi radialis, but it is not indicated by the arrow in the image.

questions.text: A patient presents with hypothenar muscle wasting and loss of sensation of medial one and a half digits. Which nerve is involved
questions.solution:
Correct option  C. Ulnar.

  • The symptoms described, hypothenar muscle wasting and loss of sensation of the medial one and a half digits, indicate the involvement of the ulnar nerve.
  • The ulnar nerve is responsible for the innervation of the hypothenar muscles (located in the palm of the hand) and provides sensory innervation to the medial one and a half digits (the little finger and half of the ring finger).

Incorrect Options :

Option A. Musculocutaneous: The musculocutaneous nerve supplies the anterior arm muscles but not the hypothenar muscles or sensation to the described digits.

Option B. Radial: The radial nerve innervates the extensor muscles of the arm and forearm and does not supply the hypothenar muscles or provide sensory innervation to the described digits.

Option D. Median: The median nerve supplies the muscles of the anterior compartment of the forearm and does not innervate the hypothenar muscles or provide sensory innervation to the described digits.

questions.text: An injury to the shown area can lead to fracture of which bone
questions.solution:
Correct Option  B: 

  • Injuries to the anatomical snuffbox can lead to fractures of the scaphoid bone, which is one of the carpal bones located in the wrist.
  • The scaphoid bone is vulnerable to fractures due to its location and shape.
  • Fractures of the scaphoid bone can result from a fall onto an outstretched hand, particularly when the force is transmitted through the thumb.

Incorrect Options :

Option A. Lunate: The lunate is another carpal bone, but it is not directly associated with the anatomical snuffbox.

Option C. Hamate: The hamate is a carpal bone located on the ulnar side of the wrist and is not directly associated with the anatomical snuffbox.

Option D. Trapezium: The trapezium is a carpal bone located at the base of the thumb, but it is not part of the anatomical snuffbox

questions.text: Which muscle originates from the medial epicondyle of the humerus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C

The muscle that originates from the medial epicondyle of the humerus is the pronator teres muscle. The pronator teres is located in the forearm and is responsible for pronating the forearm, which means rotating the forearm from a palm-up (supine) position to a palm-down (pronated) position.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Supinator: The supinator muscle, situated in the forearm's posterior compartment, isn't rooted in the medial epicondyle of the humerus.

Option B. Pronator quadratus: The pronator quadratus muscle, deep in the forearm, isn't linked to the medial epicondyle of the humerus.

Option D. Brachioradialis: The brachioradialis muscle originates from the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus, not the medial epicondyle.

questions.text: Identify the type of joint shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Syndesmosis:

  • The image is of the middle radio ulnar joint which is formed by the interosseous ligament. This is a type of fibrous joint which is syndesmosis. The syndesmosis is a type of joint that is formed by the union of two bones by a strong, fibrous tissue called a ligament. This type of joint is found in areas where stability is more important than mobility, such as the distal tibiofibular joint in the ankle and the distal radioulnar joint in the wrist.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Symphysis: Symphysis joints fuse two bones with fibrocartilage, allowing limited movement crucial for shock absorption and flexibility, like in the pelvis and spine.

Option C - Synchondrosis: Synchondrosis joints are formed by hyaline cartilage connecting two bones, commonly found in areas of growth and development like children's epiphyseal plates. 

Option D - Synostosis: Synostosis occurs when bones fuse due to various reasons like trauma or congenital conditions, leading to no mobility. Examples include cranial suture and radius-ulna fusion.

questions.text: Which single muscle is involved in the actions of arm's flexion, adduction and medial rotation?
questions.solution:
Correct option C:

  • Pectoralis major muscle is involved in the actions of arm's flexion, adduction, and medial rotation.
  • It is a large muscle located in the chest region and plays a significant role in various movements of the shoulder joint.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Serratus Anterior: This muscle is primarily involved in protraction and upward rotation of the scapula.

Option  C. Pectoralis minor: This muscle assists in stabilizing the scapula and has a role in protraction and downward rotation of the scapula.

Option  D. Subclavius: This muscle helps to stabilize and depress the clavicle.
