questions.text: The rotator cuff includes the following muscles all except;
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C.

  • Teres major: The teres major muscle is not considered part of the rotator cuff. It is a larger muscle located on the posterior side of the upper arm and is responsible for adduction and medial rotation of the arm.

Incorrect Options:

Options A. Supraspinatus: The supraspinatus muscle is one of the four muscles that make up the rotator cuff. It is located on the posterior side of the shoulder joint and assists in shoulder abduction.

Options B. Infraspinatus: The infraspinatus muscle is another muscle that is part of the rotator cuff. It is situated below the supraspinatus muscle and is responsible for lateral rotation of the arm.

Options D. Teres minor: The teres minor muscle is also included in the rotator cuff. It is located below the infraspinatus muscle and aids in lateral rotation of the arm.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient after an injury presented with a deformity as shown in the image. Which nerve will be damaged in the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Radial Nerve

  • In the given scenario, the image displaying wrist drop and a fracture of the shaft of the humerus is indicative of damage to the radial nerve

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ulnar Nerve: The ulnar nerve mainly innervates forearm and hand muscles for wrist flexion and finger abduction. It's not typically involved in wrist drop.

Option C - Median Nerve: The median nerve innervates specific forearm muscles and the hand's anterior compartment but isn't heavily involved in wrist extension, the main problem in the image.

Option D - Musculocutaneous Nerve: The musculocutaneous nerve mainly innervates the anterior arm muscles, like the biceps brachii, aiding in elbow flexion, not wrist extension.

questions.text: Which bone is most likely to be fractured in an injury to the anatomical snuff box?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Scaphoid

  • The anatomical snuff box is a triangular depression located on the radial aspect of the dorsum (back) of the hand. It is formed by the tendons of the extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis muscles. Fractures within the anatomical snuff box are commonly associated with falls onto an outstretched hand, particularly with the wrist extended. The most fractured bone in this region is the scaphoid bone, also known as the navicular bone.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lunar (lunate) bone: The lunate bone, found in the wrist joint, rarely fractures in injuries to the anatomical snuff box and isn't usually part of its formation.

Option C - Cuboid bone: The cuboid bone is one of the tarsal bones located in the foot. It is not related to the anatomical snuff box or the wrist region.

Option D - Trapezius: The trapezius is a large muscle located in the upper back and neck area. It is not a bone and is not related to the anatomical snuff box or wrist injuries.

questions.text: The given finding is associated with ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Trisomy 21

  • Trisomy 21, commonly known as Down syndrome, results from an extra copy of chromosome 21. People with Down syndrome often have distinct facial features, intellectual disabilities, and certain medical problems. Approximately half of individuals with Down syndrome have a single transverse palmar crease, making this the correct answer. The simian crease is relatively common in Down syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Trisomy 13: Trisomy 13, or Patau syndrome, results from an extra chromosome 13, leading to severe developmental issues and congenital abnormalities. While hand anomalies are common, a simian crease isn't typically present.

Option C - Klinefelter's syndrome: Klinefelter's syndrome in males with an extra X chromosome (XXY) leads to male hypogonadism and physical differences, but it's not usually linked to a simian crease.

Option D - Trisomy 18: Trisomy 18, or Edwards syndrome, stems from an extra chromosome 18, leading to severe developmental delays, intellectual disabilities, and congenital anomalies. While hand abnormalities may occur, a simian crease isn't a defining trait.

questions.text: The marked muscle is supplied by which nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Musculocutaneous nerve:

  • The muscle that is marked in the diagram is the biceps brachii.
  • The three muscles innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve in the anterior part of the arm: biceps brachii, coracobrachialis, and brachialis.
  • The terminal branch of the lateral cord of the brachial plexus is the musculocutaneous nerve.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Radial nerve supplies the triceps brachii, brachioradialis, etc. it does not supply the biceps brachii.

Option B - Ulnar nerve does not supply biceps brachii. It innervates the forearm and hand muscles

Option C - Median nerve does not supply biceps brachii. Some of the muscles innervated by the median nerve are flexor carpi radialis, palmaris longus, etc.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent structures of the brachial plexus does not provide any branches?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D.

  • Divisions: Division does not give branches in the Brachial Plexus.
  • However, the Root, cords, trunks in the brachial plexus do give branches.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B & C:Root, Cord and Tunks give branches

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the lesion of the structure indicated by the arrow?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D.

  •  The lesion marked by the arrow leads to wrist drop. Wrist drop refers to a condition where the wrist is unable to maintain an extended position and hangs in a flexed position. It occurs due to weakness or paralysis of the muscles that extend the wrist, particularly the extensor muscles in the posterior compartment of the forearm. The most common cause of wrist drop is damage or compression of the radial nerve, which innervates these muscles.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Ape thumb deformity is when the thumb aligns more with the fingers, resembling an ape's thumb. It often occurs due to median nerve injuries..

Option B. Claw hand is a deformity marked by hyperextended metacarpophalangeal joints and flexed interphalangeal joints, giving the hand a claw-like look. It's commonly linked to ulnar nerve injuries.

Option C. Claudication is muscle pain due to poor blood flow during exercise, often in lower limbs, linked to peripheral artery disease.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image given below:-
questions.solution:
Option B-Ulnar Artery:

  • The structure marked in the image is the ulnar artery. The ulnar artery is one of the main arteries in the forearm and hand. It runs along the ulnar side (medial side) of the forearm and supplies blood to the muscles and tissues of the forearm and hand.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. The structure marked in the image isn't the ulnar nerve, which provides motor and sensory innervation to the hand and forearm as a separate anatomical entity.

Option C. The structure in the image isn't the superficial radial artery, which is situated on the radial (lateral) side of the forearm, nearer to the skin surface.

Option D. The structure in the image isn't the median nerve, a major nerve in the arm that provides motor and sensory innervation to the hand and forearm.

questions.text: What is the function of the muscle indicated in the provided image?
questions.solution:
• Correct Option C - Abduction of shoulder joint

  • The muscle marked in the question is the supraspinatus, which is present above the spine of the scapula and helps abduct the shoulder joint. The muscles involved in abducting the shoulder joint are the deltoid muscle, supraspinatus muscle, and the trapezius muscle

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Retraction of scapula: The muscles involved in retracting the scapula are the middle and lower trapezius muscles and the rhomboid major and minor muscles.

Option B - Protraction of scapula: The muscles involved in protracting the scapula are the serratus anterior muscle.

Option D - Adduction of shoulder joint: The muscles involved in adducting the shoulder joint are the latissimus dorsi muscle, pectoralis major muscle, and the teres major muscle.

questions.text: Which among the following aids in supination and pronation of the forearm?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pivot joint:

  • The forearm's radius and ulna bones are connected at the elbow joint to the upper arm's humerus bone. This joint allows for rotational movements like supination (palm up) and pronation (palm down) as the radius rotates around the stationary ulna. It's a pivot joint, permitting movement around a single axis, supported by ligaments and muscles for stability and control of motion range.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Saddle joint: A saddle joint in the thumb enables a wide range of motion in multiple directions but isn't involved in the forearm's rotational movement.

Option C - Ellipsoid joint: An ellipsoid joint is a type of joint found in the wrist. It allows for movement in two planes but not rotation around a single axis.  

Option D - Ball and socket joint: A ball and socket joint is found in the hip and shoulder joints and does not play a significant role in the rotational movement of the forearm.

questions.text: Identify the anatomical structure marked in the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Extensor pollicis longus:

  • The pointed structure in the shown image is the medial boundary of the anatomical snuffbox which is away from the thumb formed by the extensor pollicis longus muscle. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Abductor pollicis brevis: The abductor pollicis brevis muscle in the forearm assists in thumb abduction and borders the anatomical snuffbox.

Option B - Extensor pollicis brevis: The extensor pollicis brevis muscle, situated in the forearm, extends the thumb and lies alongside the anatomical snuffbox.

Option C - Abductor pollicis longus: The abductor pollicis longus muscle, in the forearm, aids in wrist abduction and lies near the proximal border of the anatomical snuffbox.
